question: What is the primary action of the subscapularis muscle?
short_explanation: The subscapularis internally rotates the humerus.
long_explanation: As one of the rotator cuff muscles, subscapularis originates on the subscapular fossa and inserts on the lesser tubercle of the humerus. Its primary action is internal (medial) rotation of the shoulder.
clinical_application: Restricted internal rotation can suggest subscapularis tightness or dysfunction, which massage therapists may address through myofascial release or trigger point therapy.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

question: Which of the following bones serves as the origin for the subscapularis muscle?
short_explanation: The subscapularis originates on the anterior surface of the scapula.
long_explanation: The subscapularis originates from the subscapular fossa, which is the broad, concave surface on the anterior (costal) side of the scapula.
clinical_application: Palpation of subscapularis requires caution and is often done with the client in side-lying or supine, reaching under the scapula.

question: The subscapularis inserts onto which bony landmark?
short_explanation: It inserts onto the lesser tubercle of the humerus.
long_explanation: The subscapularis tendon attaches to the lesser tubercle of the humerus, distinguishing it from other rotator cuff muscles that insert on the greater tubercle.
clinical_application: Understanding the insertion helps locate areas of strain or inflammation during assessment or treatment.

question: Subscapularis is part of which muscle group?
short_explanation: It is one of the four rotator cuff muscles.
long_explanation: The rotator cuff includes the subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor. These muscles stabilize and move the glenohumeral joint.
clinical_application: Rotator cuff injuries often involve more than one muscle. Understanding the group helps guide evaluation.
source_reference: Trail Guide to the Body, 6th Ed.

question: Which nerve innervates the subscapularis muscle?
short_explanation: The upper and lower subscapular nerves supply the muscle.
long_explanation: The subscapularis receives innervation from the upper and lower subscapular nerves, which branch from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5–C7).
clinical_application: Neuromuscular assessment can evaluate function of these nerves, especially after shoulder trauma or compression injuries.

question: Which clinical test is commonly used to assess the integrity of the subscapularis?
short_explanation: The lift-off test evaluates subscapularis function.
long_explanation: The lift-off test requires the patient to place the back of their hand on the lower back and lift it away. Inability to do so indicates possible subscapularis weakness or rupture.
clinical_application: Massage therapists may refer clients for further evaluation if shoulder internal rotation is weak or painful with this test.

correctAnswer: Holds humeral head in the glenoid
question: What role does the subscapularis play in shoulder joint stability?
options: Holds humeral head in the glenoid
short_explanation: It helps hold the humeral head in the glenoid cavity.
long_explanation: As a rotator cuff muscle, subscapularis provides dynamic stabilization by compressing the head of the humerus into the glenoid fossa during arm movement.
clinical_application: Weakness or tears in the subscapularis can contribute to shoulder instability or anterior dislocations.

question: Which motion would most directly stretch the subscapularis?
short_explanation: External rotation of the shoulder stretches the subscapularis.
long_explanation: Subscapularis internally rotates the shoulder. Stretching it requires external rotation, especially with the arm abducted to 90 degrees.
clinical_application: Stretching this muscle is important in shoulder rehabilitation and can reduce compensatory movement patterns.

correctAnswer: Thumb pressure under scapula with arm abducted
question: Which type of massage technique is most effective for accessing subscapularis?
options: Thumb pressure under scapula with arm abducted
short_explanation: Side-lying or supine access with thumb pressure under scapula is most effective.
long_explanation: Subscapularis lies between the scapula and ribcage. It is best accessed with the client’s arm abducted, allowing the therapist to slide fingers or thumbs under the scapula from anterior.
clinical_application: This technique must be done with caution and permission, as it is near sensitive structures and can be uncomfortable.

correctAnswer: Decelerates external rotation and initiates internal rotation
question: Subscapularis contributes to which motion during the throwing phase in overhead athletes?
options: Decelerates external rotation and initiates internal rotation
short_explanation: It decelerates external rotation and initiates internal rotation.
long_explanation: During the throwing motion, especially in the follow-through, subscapularis helps slow down excessive external rotation and initiates internal rotation, protecting the anterior capsule.
clinical_application: In overhead athletes, subscapularis strains or fatigue can contribute to shoulder pain or instability.
